channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Author Correction: Stepwise activation of a metabotropic glutamate receptor
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07470-5

Author Correction: Stepwise activation of a metabotropic glutamate receptor
item.dc:title: Author Correction: Stepwise activation of a metabotropic glutamate receptor
item.dc:creator: Kaavya Krishna Kumar

item.title: From multiverses to cities: Books in brief
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01277-0

Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.
item.dc:title: From multiverses to cities: Books in brief
item.dc:creator: Andrew Robinson

item.title: Streamlined skull helps foxes take a nosedive
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01267-2

Some fox species leap up and pounce head first into snow to capture prey that they hear below the surface. An analysis of the forces involved reveals how the shape of the skull has evolved to minimize damage from this behaviour.
item.dc:title: Streamlined skull helps foxes take a nosedive
item.dc:creator: Mary Abraham

item.title: Mount Etna’s spectacular smoke rings and more — April’s best science images
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01250-x

The month’s sharpest science shots, selected by Nature’s photo team.
item.dc:title: Mount Etna’s spectacular smoke rings and more — April’s best science images
item.dc:creator: Emma Stoye

item.title: Hunger on campus: why US PhD students are fighting over food
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01279-y

Graduate students are relying on donated and discounted food in the struggle to make ends meet.
item.dc:title: Hunger on campus: why US PhD students are fighting over food
item.dc:creator: Laurie Udesky

item.title: France’s research mega-campus faces leadership crisis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01319-7

The contest to elect the next president of Paris-Saclay University has collapsed, reflecting wider issues at the giant research centre.
item.dc:title: France’s research mega-campus faces leadership crisis
item.dc:creator: Barbara Casassus

item.title: Smarty plants? Controversial plant-intelligence studies explored in new book
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01275-2

A deep dive into plant behaviour and consciousness asks why the topic has been taboo for so long, and whether botanists are changing their minds about plants’ cognitive abilities.
item.dc:title: Smarty plants? Controversial plant-intelligence studies explored in new book
item.dc:creator: Beronda L. Montgomery

item.title: A quantum solid made of electrons: observing the elusive Wigner crystal
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01211-4

In ordinary materials, electrons move too quickly for their negative electric charges to affect their interactions. But at low temperatures and densities, they can be made to crystallize into an exotic type of electron solid — a phenomenon predicted by Eugene Wigner 90 years ago and only now directly observed.
item.dc:title: A quantum solid made of electrons: observing the elusive Wigner crystal

item.title: Dark energy is tearing the Universe apart. What if the force is weakening?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01273-4

The first set of results from a pioneering cosmic-mapping project hints that the repulsive force known as dark energy has changed over 11 billion years, which would alter ideas about how the Universe has evolved and what its future will be.
item.dc:title: Dark energy is tearing the Universe apart. What if the force is weakening?
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Who’s making chips for AI? Chinese manufacturers lag behind US tech giants
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01292-1

Researchers in China say they are finding themselves five to ten years behind their US counterparts as export restrictions bite.
item.dc:title: Who’s making chips for AI? Chinese manufacturers lag behind US tech giants
item.dc:creator: Jonathan O'Callaghan

item.title: Daniel Kahneman obituary: psychologist who revolutionized the way we think about thinking
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01344-6

Nobel prizewinner whose insights into the foibles of human decision-making launched the field of behavioural economics and sent ripples through all social sciences.
item.dc:title: Daniel Kahneman obituary: psychologist who revolutionized the way we think about thinking
item.dc:creator: Eldar Shafir

item.title: Changing rainforest to plantations shifts tropical food webs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00434-9

A study provides insights into how energy flows in the food webs that connect soil- and canopy-dwelling organisms in tropical ecosystems with high biodiversity. When rainforest is converted to plantations, food webs are simplified and restructured, leading to profound changes in tropical-ecosystem functioning.
item.dc:title: Changing rainforest to plantations shifts tropical food webs

item.title: A deconstruction-reconstruction strategy for pyrimidine diversification
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07474-1

A deconstruction-reconstruction strategy for pyrimidine diversification
item.dc:title: A deconstruction-reconstruction strategy for pyrimidine diversification
item.dc:creator: Benjamin J. H. Uhlenbruck
Celena M. Josephitis
Louis de Lescure
Robert S. Paton
Andrew McNally

item.title: Never mind little green men: life on other planets might be purple
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01261-8

Bacteria that make food using a compound other than chlorophyll could paint other planets in a wide range of colours.
item.dc:title: Never mind little green men: life on other planets might be purple

item.title: ‘Orangutan, heal thyself’: First wild animal seen using medicinal plant
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01289-w

The Sumatran orangutan used a plant known to humans for its medicinal qualities.
item.dc:title: ‘Orangutan, heal thyself’: First wild animal seen using medicinal plant
item.dc:creator: Gayathri Vaidyanathan

item.title: UTIs make life miserable — scientists are finding new ways to tackle them
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01322-y

Researchers are developing vaccines and fresh drug approaches to prevent and treat recurring infections without antibiotics.
item.dc:title: UTIs make life miserable — scientists are finding new ways to tackle them
item.dc:creator: Carissa Wong

item.title: US National Academies report outlines barriers and solutions for scientist carers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01334-8

Carers need better support from employers, such as paid parental leave, subsidized childcare and relief for other types of caregiving. But is there will among institutions to provide it?
item.dc:title: US National Academies report outlines barriers and solutions for scientist carers
item.dc:creator: Amanda Heidt

item.title: My PI yelled at me and I’m devastated. What do I do?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01309-9

It can be hard when junior scientists feel unsupported. Nature asked three scientists for their advice on how to respond.
item.dc:title: My PI yelled at me and I’m devastated. What do I do?
item.dc:creator: Nikki Forrester

item.title: A body–brain circuit that regulates body inflammatory responses
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07469-y

A body–brain circuit that regulates body inflammatory responses
item.dc:title: A body–brain circuit that regulates body inflammatory responses
item.dc:creator: Hao Jin
Mengtong Li
Eric Jeong
Felipe Castro-Martinez
Charles S. Zuker

item.title: Magnetic field effects on behaviour in Drosophila
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07319-x

Magnetic field effects on behaviour in Drosophila
item.dc:title: Magnetic field effects on behaviour in Drosophila
item.dc:creator: Steven M. Reppert

item.title: A magnetic liquid makes for an injectable sensor in living tissue
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01262-7

Fluid studded with microscopic magnetic particles can be inserted into the body and later retrieved.
item.dc:title: A magnetic liquid makes for an injectable sensor in living tissue

item.title: Pandemic lockdowns were less of a shock for people with fewer ties
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01260-9

During periods of enforced isolation, life satisfaction for older adults took less of a hit in those who were already socially isolated.
item.dc:title: Pandemic lockdowns were less of a shock for people with fewer ties

item.title: Dad’s microbiome can affect offspring’s health — in mice
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01313-z

Disrupting gut microbes increases risk of growth issues in the next generation, and understanding geographic variations in cancer rates.
item.dc:title: Dad’s microbiome can affect offspring’s health — in mice
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson
Nick Petrić Howe

item.title: Sex and gender discussions don't need to be toxic
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01311-1

The science of sex and gender is too often misinterpreted and weaponized. Now, three experts cut through the misinformation in search of a positive future for this long-neglected area of research
item.dc:title: Sex and gender discussions don't need to be toxic
item.dc:creator: Lucy Odling-Smee
Florence Ashley
Stacey A. Ritz
Margaret M. McCarthy
Noah Baker

item.title: Magnetic field responses in Drosophila
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07320-4

Magnetic field responses in Drosophila
item.dc:title: Magnetic field responses in Drosophila
item.dc:creator: Charalambos P. Kyriacou

item.title: Paternal microbiome perturbations impact offspring fitness
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07336-w

Disturbances in the gut microbiota of male mice manifest as fitness defects in their offspring by affecting plancenta function, revealing a paternal gut–germline axis.
item.dc:title: Paternal microbiome perturbations impact offspring fitness

item.title: Sleep pressure modulates single-neuron synapse number in zebrafish
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07367-3

Synapses are gained during spontaneous or forced periods of wake and lost during sleep in a neuron-subtype-dependent manner in zebrafish.
item.dc:title: Sleep pressure modulates single-neuron synapse number in zebrafish
item.dc:creator: Anya Suppermpool
Declan G. Lyons
Elizabeth Broom
Jason Rihel

item.title: Structural basis of lipid head group entry to the Kennedy pathway by FLVCR1
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07374-4

A structural, biochemical and metabolomic analysis reveals the mechanistic basis for transport of extracellular choline and ethanolamine into cells by the human transport protein FLVCR1.
item.dc:title: Structural basis of lipid head group entry to the Kennedy pathway by FLVCR1
item.dc:creator: Yeeun Son
Timothy C. Kenny
Artem Khan
Kıvanç Birsoy
Richard K. Hite

item.title: Probing single electrons across 300-mm spin qubit wafers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07275-6

Using a cryogenic 300-mm wafer prober, a new approach for the testing of hundreds of industry-manufactured spin qubit devices at 1.6 K provides high-volume data on performance, allowing optimization of the complementary metal–oxide–semiconductor (CMOS)-compatible fabrication process.
item.dc:title: Probing single electrons across 300-mm spin qubit wafers

item.title: Airway hillocks are injury-resistant reservoirs of unique plastic stem cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07377-1

In the lungs, recently identified epithelial structures known as hillocks can act as injury-resistant reservoirs of stem cells.
item.dc:title: Airway hillocks are injury-resistant reservoirs of unique plastic stem cells

item.title: Geographic variation of mutagenic exposures in kidney cancer genomes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07368-2

Whole-genome sequencing of 962 clear cell renal cell carcinomas from 11 countries shows geographic variations in somatic mutation profiles, including a mutational signature of unknown cause in 70% of cases from Japan.
item.dc:title: Geographic variation of mutagenic exposures in kidney cancer genomes

item.title: Mechanics of human embryo compaction
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07351-x

Using micropipette aspiration on donated human embryos, cell surface tensions during compaction were mapped, indicating a role for defective cell contractility in poor quality embryos.
item.dc:title: Mechanics of human embryo compaction
item.dc:creator: Julie Firmin
Nicolas Ecker

item.title: Temporal dynamics of the multi-omic response to endurance exercise training
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06877-w

Temporal multi-omic analysis of tissues from rats undergoing up to eight weeks of endurance exercise training reveals widespread shared, tissue-specific and sex-specific changes, including immune, metabolic, stress response and mitochondrial pathways.
item.dc:title: Temporal dynamics of the multi-omic response to endurance exercise training

item.title: 3D genomic mapping reveals multifocality of human pancreatic precancers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07359-3

Quantitative multimodal 3D reconstruction of human pancreatic tissue at single-cell resolution reveals a high burden of multifocal, genetically heterogeneous pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasias in the normal adult pancreas.
item.dc:title: 3D genomic mapping reveals multifocality of human pancreatic precancers

item.title: Chromatin accessibility during human first-trimester neurodevelopment
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07234-1

A study describes chromatin accessibility and paired gene expression across the entire developing human brain during the first trimester in the context of gene regulation and neurodevelopmental disease.
item.dc:title: Chromatin accessibility during human first-trimester neurodevelopment

item.title: Bevel-edge epitaxy of ferroelectric rhombohedral boron nitride single crystal
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07286-3

Centimetre-sized single-crystal rhombohedral boron nitride layers are achieved through bevel-edge epitaxy, and the resulting material exhibits robust, homogeneous and switchable ferroelectricity with a high Curie temperature.
item.dc:title: Bevel-edge epitaxy of ferroelectric rhombohedral boron nitride single crystal
item.dc:creator: Li Wang

item.title: Mitochondrial transfer mediates endothelial cell engraftment through mitophagy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07340-0

Under stressful conditions, mesenchymal stromal cells transfer mitochondria to endothelial cells through tunnelling nanotubes, and artificially transplanting mitochondria into endothelial cells improves the ability of these cells to engraft and to revascularize ischaemic tissues.
item.dc:title: Mitochondrial transfer mediates endothelial cell engraftment through mitophagy
item.dc:creator: Ruei-Zeng Lin

Yonglin Zhu
Xuechong Hong
Joseph Neumeyer
Hong-Wen Tang
Norbert Perrimon
Juan M. Melero-Martin

item.title: Frequent disturbances enhanced the resilience of past human populations
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07354-8

Analysis of population decline shows that frequent disturbances enhance a population’s capacity to resist and recover from downturns and that trade-offs exist when adopting new or alternative land-use strategies.
item.dc:title: Frequent disturbances enhanced the resilience of past human populations
item.dc:creator: Philip Riris
Fabio Silva
Enrico Crema
Alessio Palmisano
Erick Robinson
Peter E. Siegel
Jennifer C. French

item.title: Structural and molecular basis of choline uptake into the brain by FLVCR2
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07326-y

FLVCR2 is expressed in the blood–brain barrier of mouse and human, and is the major mediator of choline uptake into the brain.
item.dc:title: Structural and molecular basis of choline uptake into the brain by FLVCR2

item.title: Multimodal decoding of human liver regeneration
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07376-2

Harnessing single-nucleus RNA sequencing and spatial profiling, this work dissects unanticipated aspects of human liver regeneration to uncover a novel migratory hepatocyte subpopulation mediating wound closure following acute liver injury.
item.dc:title: Multimodal decoding of human liver regeneration

item.title: Stereoselective amino acid synthesis by photobiocatalytic oxidative coupling
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07284-5

We report on the oxidative cross-coupling of organoboron reagents and amino acids via pyridoxal biocatalysis to produce non-canonical amino acids, uncovering stereoselective, intermolecular free-radical transformations.
item.dc:title: Stereoselective amino acid synthesis by photobiocatalytic oxidative coupling
item.dc:creator: Tian-Ci Wang
Binh Khanh Mai
Zheng Zhang
Zhiyu Bo
Jiedong Li
Peng Liu
Yang Yang

item.title: Endurance exercise causes a multi-organ full-body molecular reaction
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00585-9

A study of male and female rats has examined the biomolecular changes induced in many of their organs by eight weeks of endurance treadmill training. The findings offer insights into the many benefits to our immune, metabolic and stress-response pathways as we adapt to exercise.
item.dc:title: Endurance exercise causes a multi-organ full-body molecular reaction

item.title: How I’m supporting other researchers who have moved to Lithuania
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01142-0

Biochemist Stephen Knox Jones chose a role in the Baltic country over other faculty positions in Denmark and the United States. He explains why.
item.dc:title: How I’m supporting other researchers who have moved to Lithuania
item.dc:creator: Jacqui Thornton

item.title: Intel brings quantum-computing microchips a step closer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01208-z

By adapting methods for fabricating and testing conventional computer chips, researchers have brought silicon-based quantum computers closer to reality — and to accessing the immense benefits of a mature chipmaking industry.
item.dc:title: Intel brings quantum-computing microchips a step closer
item.dc:creator: Ruoyu Li

item.title: Chinese virologist who was first to share COVID-19 genome sleeps on street after lab shuts
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01293-0

Zhang Yongzhen shared the genomic sequence of SARS-CoV-2 with the world, speeding up the development of vaccines.
item.dc:title: Chinese virologist who was first to share COVID-19 genome sleeps on street after lab shuts
item.dc:creator: Smriti Mallapaty

item.title: Plagiarism in peer-review reports could be the ‘tip of the iceberg’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01312-0

Researchers say swathe of copied text could indicate a widespread problem.
item.dc:title: Plagiarism in peer-review reports could be the ‘tip of the iceberg’
item.dc:creator: Jackson Ryan

item.title: Scientists tried to give people COVID — and failed
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01284-1

Researchers deliberately infect participants with SARS-CoV-2 in ‘challenge’ trials — but high levels of immunity complicate efforts to test vaccines and treatments.
item.dc:title: Scientists tried to give people COVID — and failed
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: I fell out of love with the lab, and in love with business
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01140-2

The COVID-19 pandemic changed Karolina Makovskytė’s career ambitions, propelling her to a business development role in her home nation of Lithuania.
item.dc:title: I fell out of love with the lab, and in love with business
item.dc:creator: Jacqui Thornton

item.title: Controversial virus-hunting scientist skewered at US COVID-origins hearing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01305-z

Lawmakers interrogated Peter Daszak over his ties to China and whether his organization, EcoHealth Alliance, has been a good steward of taxpayer dollars.
item.dc:title: Controversial virus-hunting scientist skewered at US COVID-origins hearing
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo
Lauren Wolf

item.title: How to meet Africa’s grand challenges with African know-how
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01249-4

Simple measures to strengthen the interface between science, policy and society in African nations could help the continent leapfrog others in sustainable innovation and development.
item.dc:title: How to meet Africa’s grand challenges with African know-how
item.dc:creator: Alfred R. Bizoza

item.title: We need more-nuanced approaches to exploring sex and gender in research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01204-3

Some scientists are reluctant to investigate questions about sex and gender, particularly given today’s sociopolitical tensions around gender identity. But they should lean in and embrace the complexity.
item.dc:title: We need more-nuanced approaches to exploring sex and gender in research
item.dc:creator: Stacey A. Ritz
Lorraine Greaves

item.title: Daily briefing: What scientists think of Netflix’s 3 Body Problem
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01317-9

The scientific adviser of 3 Body Problem, a planetary scientist and a nanotechnology expert review the hit sci-fi show. Plus, why a trailblazing Chinese virologist was sleeping in the street outside his own lab.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: What scientists think of Netflix’s 3 Body Problem
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Why it’s essential to study sex and gender, even as tensions rise
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01207-0

Some scholars are reluctant to research sex and gender out of fear that their studies will be misused. In a series of specially commissioned articles, Nature encourages scientists to engage.
item.dc:title: Why it’s essential to study sex and gender, even as tensions rise

item.title: Found: the dial in the brain that controls the immune system
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01259-2

Scientists identify the brain cells that regulate inflammation, and pinpoint how they keep tabs on the immune response.
item.dc:title: Found: the dial in the brain that controls the immune system
item.dc:creator: Giorgia Guglielmi

item.title: Genomics reveal unknown mutation-promoting agents at global sites
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01190-6

Genetic sequencing of human kidney cancers worldwide has revealed associations between geographical locations and specific mutation patterns, indicating exposure to known and unknown mutation-promoting agents.
item.dc:title: Genomics reveal unknown mutation-promoting agents at global sites
item.dc:creator: Irene Franco
Fran Supek

item.title: The AI tuner
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01219-w

If music be the food of love.
item.dc:title: The AI tuner
item.dc:creator: Joanna Friedman

item.title: How bioinformatics led one scientist home to Lithuania
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01141-1

Juozas Gordevičius founded a data-science company in the United States before returning to Vilnius.
item.dc:title: How bioinformatics led one scientist home to Lithuania
item.dc:creator: Jacqui Thornton

item.title: Allen J. Bard obituary: electrochemist whose techniques underpin clinical diagnostics, materials discovery and more
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01278-z

Innovator who pioneered scanning electrochemical microscopy, bioassays and solar fuels.
item.dc:title: Allen J. Bard obituary: electrochemist whose techniques underpin clinical diagnostics, materials discovery and more
item.dc:creator: Michael Rose
Henry S. White

item.title: Male–female comparisons are powerful in biomedical research — don’t abandon them
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01205-2

Binary sex studies have been denounced as too simplistic, but dropping them altogether would impede progress in a long-neglected area of biomedicine.
item.dc:title: Male–female comparisons are powerful in biomedical research — don’t abandon them
item.dc:creator: Arthur P. Arnold
Sabra L. Klein
Margaret M. McCarthy
Jeffrey S. Mogil

item.title: Cells destroy donated mitochondria to build blood vessels
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01233-y

Organelles called mitochondria are transferred to blood-vessel-forming cells by support cells. Unexpectedly, these mitochondria are degraded, kick-starting the production of new ones and boosting vessel formation.
item.dc:title: Cells destroy donated mitochondria to build blood vessels
item.dc:creator: Chantell S. Evans

item.title: A snapshot of Lithuania’s life-sciences landscape
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01139-9

Nature examines the Baltic country’s research ambitions as it marks 20 years of European Union membership.
item.dc:title: A snapshot of Lithuania’s life-sciences landscape
item.dc:creator: Jacqui Thornton

item.title: Why is exercise good for you? Scientists are finding answers in our cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01200-7

Decades of evidence shows that exercise leads to healthier, longer lives. Researchers are just starting to work out what it does to cells to reap this reward.
item.dc:title: Why is exercise good for you? Scientists are finding answers in our cells
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: Resilience lessons from ancient societies are still relevant today
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01189-z

What lessons can we learn from the factors that govern the resilience of human populations? A large-scale analysis examining ancient societies around the world provides a detailed look at what drives sustainability.
item.dc:title: Resilience lessons from ancient societies are still relevant today
item.dc:creator: John Haldon

item.title: Dad’s gut microbes matter for pregnancy health and baby’s growth
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01191-5

Altering gut bacteria in male mice revealed that microorganisms are needed for normal sperm development and offspring health. Scientists discuss the implications in terms of understanding microbes, male fertility and pregnancy.
item.dc:title: Dad’s gut microbes matter for pregnancy health and baby’s growth
item.dc:creator: Liisa Veerus
Martin J. Blaser
Yoel Sadovsky
Eldin Jašarević

item.title: Support communities that will lose out in the energy transition
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01248-5

Climate campaigners and politicians rightly concentrate on the benefits of clean energy — but without more support for those who are adversely affected, the backlash will only grow.
item.dc:title: Support communities that will lose out in the energy transition

item.title: Why it was right to reject the Anthropocene as a geological epoch
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01268-1

Why it was right to reject the Anthropocene as a geological epoch

item.title: How to stop students cramming for exams? Send them to sea
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01209-y

An innovative proposal to stop exam over-preparation, plus William Bateson’s 1924 take on the previous century of biology, in the weekly dip into Nature’s archive.
item.dc:title: How to stop students cramming for exams? Send them to sea

item.title: Not just truffles: dogs can sniff out surpassingly rare native fungus
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01263-6

Daisy, a member of a breed used to find fungal delicacies, detected a critically endangered Australian fungus faster than a trained human could.
item.dc:title: Not just truffles: dogs can sniff out surpassingly rare native fungus

item.title: AI & robotics briefing: What running robots tell us about gaits
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01307-x

A robot that changes from trot to bounce to avoid falls hints at why four-legged animals transition between gaits. Plus, AI designs new gene-editing tools and how autonomous weapons are changing war.
item.dc:title: AI & robotics briefing: What running robots tell us about gaits

item.title: The science of 3 Body Problem: what’s fact and what’s fiction?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01272-5

Nature spoke to the sci-fi programme’s adviser and two other researchers about the portrayal of PhD scientists and their technologies.
item.dc:title: The science of 3 Body Problem: what’s fact and what’s fiction?

item.title: This social sciences hub galvanized India’s dynamic growth. Can it survive?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00944-6

The Centre for Policy Research has lost its chief executive, most of its staff and is running out of cash.
item.dc:title: This social sciences hub galvanized India’s dynamic growth. Can it survive?
